article.title: opinion A curfew won't save Indianapolis teens. Investment in them
article.content:
opinion
A curfew won't save Indianapolis teens. Investment in them will. | Opinion

Teens are seeking stimulation because they're bored, connection because they're lonely and support we've taken away from them.

It was half past midnight. We were returning from a wedding, stunned at the sight of hundreds of teens lining the sidewalks downtown. I recognized one as my student, Dakari. The next morning, I saw the headline: gunfire, 2 a.m., three teens wounded. They never identify juveniles by name. For teachers, it’s torturous — were they one of ours?

I stopped Dakari in the hall Monday. “I clocked you out late Saturday night. Everything good?” Dakari is a natural leader, unafraid of truth, which earned him the respect of his classmates. And luckily, he trusted me. Yeah, he was less than a block away. He was shaken, but unhurt. “I hope that’s the last time you’re out that late," I said.

“Nah, we’re going out again next weekend.”

My heart sank at his response. It sank again when Indianapolis approved its new curfew this month — including a proposal to charge parents fines. It seems easy, right? But easy solutions are rarely good ones.

Briggs: Mike Braun grandstands on Indianapolis crime while murders drop 24%

Indianapolis has become a city that is afraid of its own children. I see teens demonized across social media as “feral” and “violent.” But these same teens are the most creative, savvy and thoughtful students I know. They are full of ideas about how to improve their community, and they jump at the chance to help. Unfortunately, we offer few ways to use these aptitudes.

We're offering teens too little help

Students in out-of-school programs have lower absenteeism and delinquency and better scores and earnings. In Baltimore, targeted youth programs almost single-handedly cut violence by a third. But in Indiana, we don’t have enough programs for them. For every child in one, three more are waitlisted, with demand outpacing supply.

Meanwhile, the percentage of children alone and unsupervised has actually decreased. However, being home doesn’t mean children are safe. More youth are depressed, isolated or contemplating suicide than ever before, especially teen girls. And more teens are armed with guns and dying from them, including in rural counties. Safe storage proposals routinely fail, so Indiana has one of the highest rates of accidental child shootings in the country.

So why are so many teens out after dark? Like most of his peers, Dakari wasn’t out there to hurt anyone — he was there because his friends and family were there. Implemented alone, a curfew is a band-aid that makes isolation worse. A lasting solution must address root causes.

Teens are seeking what we all need


Teens are seeking stimulation because they’re bored. Out-of-school programs may be facing federal freezes and state shortfalls, but local parks, libraries, and nonprofits are a nexus for youth sports, clubs, arts, education and volunteering. But Indy’s parks are woefully underfunded — we pay less than half the national median. Our libraries once fared better, but recent cuts have decimated that lead. It’s no wonder Indiana ranks bottom ten for supporting children. We must invest more.

Teens are seeking connection because they’re lonely. Teens were spending less time with friends even before COVID, but they’re also isolated from their families — 40% of children lack strong emotional bonds with their parents. One solution is having mentor-like adults outside home. But young people report fewer mentor figures than ever. Older people describe their teenage years as full of feedback from adults in their community. That community has fragmented, and youth mental health has deteriorated alongside it. We can all do more to engage youth in our neighborhoods.

Briggs: Fountain Square camp shows Indianapolis' homelessness strategy is broken

Finally, teens are seeking support. But we’ve designed a system that makes it almost impossible to care for our children. Indiana restricts teaching teens what could get them pregnant. New parents lack guaranteed paid parental leave. Many towns sit in tri-county childcare deserts — we rank worst in the country, costing billions. Parents must work to keep Medicaid, so kids go unsupervised. Child abuse reports often go uninvestigated, even as unhoused children sleep at DCS offices. And Indiana’s youth homelessness rate continues to balloon faster than the national rate. It’s all too easy to blame parents. Yet we’ve adopted policies that abandon them. Let’s flip that script and put families first.

I know exactly what would have kept Dakari from going downtown — he needed something better to do. We all have a role in that responsibility. Let’s make Indianapolis a city that’s safe and enriching for our youth.

Ronak Shah is a middle school science teacher in Indianapolis.

summary:
# Résultat d’analyse

## Entités extraites
- **Langue** : en
- **Personnes** : Dakari, Mike Braun, Ronak Shah
- **Lieux** : Indianapolis, Baltimore, Indiana, Indy, Fountain Square
- **Valeurs numériques** : half past midnight, 2 a.m., three (3.0 None), 24% (24.0 %), a third, one (1.0 None), three (3.0 None), 40% (40.0 %)

## Suggestions d’angles

### 1. Mapping Youth Program Deserts in Indianapolis
Visualize areas of Indianapolis with limited access to youth programs and compare them to regions with higher rates of teen incidents. This could highlight the correlation between program availability and youth activity levels.

### 2. The Cost of Curfews: Financial and Social Impacts
Analyze the financial burden of curfew fines on families and compare it to the costs of implementing comprehensive youth programs. This could reveal the economic inefficiencies of punitive measures versus supportive investments.

### 3. From Isolation to Inclusion: Rebuilding Community Bonds
Examine historical data on community engagement levels and their impact on youth well-being. This could help identify strategies to strengthen community ties and improve mental health outcomes for teens.

### 4. Investing in Youth: A Comparative Analysis of State Funding
Compare Indiana's investment in youth services with other states and assess the outcomes. Highlight which states have achieved success and explore what Indianapolis can learn from them to better support its youth.

### 5. The Rising Tide of Youth Homelessness: A Statewide Crisis
Investigate the trends in youth homelessness in Indiana and its causes. Use data visualizations to show how policy changes could address this growing issue and improve outcomes for vulnerable children.

angle_resources.title: Mapping Youth Program Deserts in Indianapolis
angle_resources.description: Visualize areas of Indianapolis with limited access to youth programs and compare them to regions with higher rates of teen incidents. This could highlight the correlation between program availability and youth activity levels.

sources.title: Youth Program and Services Data
sources.description: A database providing information on various youth programs and services available in Indianapolis.

sources.description: Provides demographic and economic data which can be used to analyze community needs and resources.

visualizations.title: Carte des déserts de programmes jeunesse à Indianapolis
visualizations.note: Utiliser les données des services municipaux et des organisations locales pour identifier les zones avec peu de programmes.

visualizations.note: Comparer les données sur les incidents adolescents avec la disponibilité des programmes pour chaque zone.

visualizations.note: Visualiser les zones avec des taux élevés d'incidents pour identifier les priorités d'intervention.

angle_resources.title: The Cost of Curfews: Financial and Social Impacts
angle_resources.description: Analyze the financial burden of curfew fines on families and compare it to the costs of implementing comprehensive youth programs. This could reveal the economic inefficiencies of punitive measures versus supportive investments.

datasets.title: INSEE Family Budgets Survey
datasets.description: Provides insights into the financial burden on families, including impacts of fines and penalties in France.

sources.title: Eurostat Crime and Criminal Justice Statistics
sources.description: Provides data on crime rates, including fines and penalties, across EU countries, useful for analyzing the financial burden of curfew fines.

sources.title: OECD Social Expenditure Database (SOCX)
sources.description: Offers data on public spending on social programs, allowing comparison with costs of implementing youth programs.

visualizations.title: Répartition des amendes de couvre-feu par revenu familial
visualizations.note: Données issues des rapports municipaux sur les amendes de couvre-feu.

visualizations.title: Comparaison des coûts : amendes vs programmes pour jeunes
visualizations.note: Inclut les coûts des amendes et les budgets des programmes jeunesse.

visualizations.title: Impact social des couvre-feux sur les jeunes
visualizations.note: Basé sur des études de cas et des enquêtes sociales.

angle_resources.title: From Isolation to Inclusion: Rebuilding Community Bonds
angle_resources.description: Examine historical data on community engagement levels and their impact on youth well-being. This could help identify strategies to strengthen community ties and improve mental health outcomes for teens.

datasets.description: Access comprehensive data on social participation and its impact on mental health within the European Union.

sources.description: Explore data on social engagement, community participation, and their effects on youth well-being across OECD countries.

sources.title: World Bank Social Capital Surveys
sources.description: Analyze data on community engagement and its correlation with youth mental health in various countries.

visualizations.title: Comparaison internationale des liens communautaires
visualizations.note: Source : Organisation mondiale de la santé, données 2023

angle_resources.title: Investing in Youth: A Comparative Analysis of State Funding
angle_resources.description: Compare Indiana's investment in youth services with other states and assess the outcomes. Highlight which states have achieved success and explore what Indianapolis can learn from them to better support its youth.
